Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of naked male (dwarf?) musician playing pipes. Legs missing. Mould-made and solid. Traces of white (gypsum?) coating and red paint. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Gutch dated this piece to between 150BC and 250AD (Hogarth 1899, Pl.12, no.174). A good parallel has been dated to the early 2nd century BC (Fischer 1994, Pl. 34. No.370). Fischer, J. 1994. ‘Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen’. Tübingen: Wasmuth.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.505) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 92, no. 174, pl. XII, no. 174)
